title: Teacher survey on crowdsourcing in a nutshel

author: Špela Arhar Holdt, Center za jezikovne vire in tehnologije (CJVT), Univerza v Ljubljani

Teachers are of course one of our major stakeholders in the network, so we wanted to know more about their current practices and their general attitude towards crowdsourcing, and mainly the stuff that we are trying to do and achieve in the network.
We wanted to know whether they were familiar with the concept of crowdsourcing, whether they were maybe already including.

Some of them reported doing different stuff with dual lingo, Wikipedia, etc.
But we have also collected their answers in the category other like if what you were doing is not listed here, please tell us what exactly the activity was.
And we have realized that many of these activities do not fall under the definition of crowdsourcing as we have provided it there many teachers.
Many participants equated crowdsourcing with any sort of cooperation.

So here we have some more more evidence and motivation to form.

Less experience than these initially would suggest.

We have asked teachers whether they would be willing to crowd source teaching materials for the languages they teach and only 4% of the people who have made it that far.
In the survey.
Of course, these are already the motivated ones.
Only four percent replied that they would not want to participate in in any case.
Almost 70% said yes and 27% said they didn't know, so they could maybe be convinced.
Up we have listed some crowdsourcing tasks that we as the community have deemed appropriate of.
You know, putting on such a list that we were interested in.
And it turns out that their preferred crowdsourcing tasks would be to collaborate with other teachers in the creation of interactive digital learning materials.

It's very important that here, this is about the creation of new materials, because we also had one answer saying that they would share their own materials and they are less willing to share their own materials then create, participate in the creation of something entirely new.
And then on the 2nd place went to selecting, editing and sharing language examples for exercises or tests.
So basically what they want is, I guess, some learning materials, digital learning materials and digital exercises and tests.
They were much less willing to participate.
Unfortunately for us, annotating data annotating language errors in participating in the creation of language, resources of any kind.
So I think here we really have to keep in mind that they will.
Be working on stuff that they can really use themselves, and that's about it.

Questions were about motivation.
Some extra information I have to read here so that we know what this was, what they were choosing from.

So this is for the students, but what would you organize for the students?
What would help you organize more crowdsourcing activities for the students?
Um, and they want.
Specific ideas they want ideas about which specific crowdsourcing activities are suitable for the languages they teach.
So here this is a very clear message to us.
We have to stop.
Talking about crowdsourcing in general, we have to start talking about specific stuff.
Specific people can do in their classroom, and then Secondly they wanted tutorials about crowdsourcing based teaching techniques, so they want to know more about crowdsourcing.
But again, we also had among the answers general tutorials about crowdsourcing and they were not picking that.
They want crowdsourcing based teaching techniques.
So they want this to be aimed specifically.
Other than some other stuff, they were choosing less often than this to give you some wider idea.

For example, they could choose more teaching time.
I thought that would win.
Improve technical equipment.
Pre prepared Lesson plan.
Indication of motivational aspect for the students.

We also asked them what technical equipment is available to your students.
Pupils at the time.

Of their students can use smartphones.
52% have classroom computers.
And everything else they could choose was less often present in the classrooms.
So computer rooms with 62%.
This is the highest we can aim at.
Now.

So I think here time of course is on our side.
We are visionaries, we are inventing solutions for the future.

Here and now, I think we have to keep this in mind.
I think it could be very.

What would motivate you to participate in crowdsourcing?
So this is for them personally.

Of course we were expecting saving time, but this learning aspect I think.
At least I personally I have under estimated that one I did not expect that one to win.
Let me tell you why, because we also had professional accreditation, peer recognition, feeling of contributing to a greater cause.
I thought maybe that One Financial compensation, a concrete finalized product.
As the result.
All of these things were selected less often as acquiring new skills and knowledge.
So I think this is again something that we can really work with in the network as well.

So we're closing.
We're moving closer to the end of this presentation, and I would like to show you some other comments teachers have made.

Which is true.

I think this is.
This is a very important question for us to answer in the near future.
So I have proposed some.
Next next steps, rebranding is what I would vouch for here with with teachers as stakeholders.
I think we have to stop talking about crowdsourcing.

We have to start talking about something new, something that will make them understand why this could be good for them, why this is similar to what they're doing, and how this could be good for their community.
For community in general.
Um, then we have to, I think, tackle this need for knowledge.
Maybe prepare some educational materials, tutorials or courses that would address these identified needs.
We have to prepare concrete scenarios.
We have to start.
As I said before, we have to start talking a little more concretely here.
The bigger picture here.
Of course, what I personally would really love to see happen.
We need to develop new platforms that would optimize crowdsourcing activities.
And results for the teaching community.
So if they want to prepare materials, we just have to give them the spot where where they can do it, exactly how they want to do it.
I think that would be very helpful.
And then of course, as I mentioned before, we have to keep in mind the reality of here and now.
Of course prepare the solutions for the future, but still stand with both feet in the reality of now.
